episodes.title: US officials find more than a million documents potentially linked to Epstein files case
episodes.description: The US Justice Department says more than a million additional documents - potentially related to convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein, have been uncovered. The DOJ says the files will be released as soon as possible. Ira Spitzer reports.

episodes.title: Beaten and raped 4-5 times a day: Former GISB member on life in the cult-linked group
episodes.description:
TW: Some might find the contents of this video disturbing.

For nearly two decades, “Zoey”, as she wants to be referred to, was a member of the Malaysian cult-linked group GISB or Global Ikhwan Services and Business Holdings, which is facing allegations of child abuse, human trafficking and religious deviance. Now a single mother to 9 children, she tells CNA that her 14-year marriage involved frequent sexual abuse and violence. In this personal account, “Zoey” details her experience with GISB and how she escaped. Read more: https://cna.asia/3UHQ2pp

episodes.title: Malaysia child abuse cases: GISB CEO and wife among 22 charged
episodes.description:
The CEO of GISB, Nasiruddin Mohd Ali, and his wife, Azura Md Yusof were among the 22 people charged in Kuala Lumpur on Wednesday (Oct 23) for being part of an organised crime group. 

The conglomerate is linked to hundreds of child abuse cases in Malaysia and has ties with banned religious sect Al-Arqam. 

Also charged was Adib At-Tamimi, the son of Al-Arqam’s founder. Read more through the link in our bio.

episodes.title: What is GISB and how is it related to Malaysia's child abuse scandal? | CNA Explains
episodes.description:
In September 2024, hundreds of children in charity homes across Malaysia were rescued from abuse. The police reported that some were sexually abused by their caretakers and were also taught to abuse other children.

Global Ikhwan Services and Business Holdings, or GISB, has been linked to these homes. The conglomerate is widely known for having ties to Al-Arqam, an outlawed sect. What is the story behind GISB and the alleged child abuse cases? Here's all you need to know.

More on how GISB managed to stay under the radar:
https://cna.asia/4ePIeti

More CNA Explains videos: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLbnMTcZEga8RZkFnvrVbOlyleVMcz1-vR

episodes.title: Who is Apollo Quiboloy, the Philippine pastor wanted by the FBI? | CNA Explains
episodes.description:
In August 2024, more than 2,000 police officers were deployed in Davao City to arrest Apollo Quiboloy, a mega-church pastor who faces multiple charges of child abuse and sex trafficking in the Philippines and the United States. Just who is this man who proclaimed himself the "appointed son of god"? Here's what you need to know. More details: https://cna.asia/4ejQaCG

episodes.title: Malaysia abuse scandal: Remand for GISB's CEO extended for another 4 days
episodes.description: Malaysian police apply and get remand extensions for several individuals, including top management at GISB, which is implicated in a case involving the alleged abuse of hundreds of children. Afifah Ariffin reports from Kuala Lumpur.

episodes.title: Malaysian police make more arrests linked to GISB-run care homes
episodes.description: Malaysian police made another round of arrests over the weekend, as they continue their probe into one of the biggest child abuse scandals in the country. Afifah Ariffin reports from Kuala Lumpur.

episodes.title: CEO of Malaysian firm linked to child abuse at welfare homes arrested in police raid
episodes.description: The CEO of Global Ikhwan Services and Business Holdings (GISB) and his wife have been detained, as Malaysian police widen their raid over a child abuse case surrounding charity homes linked to the firm. Nasiruddin Mohd Ali was among 19 people detained in an early morning raid on four residential premises in Kuala Lumpur. Over 400 children who had allegedly been exploited and sexually abused were rescued last Wednesday. They were found in some 20 welfare homes believed to be linked to GISB. 171 suspects have been arrested. Afifah Ariffin reports.

episodes.title: Man linked to Malaysian firm in alleged child abuse scandal charged with criminal intimidation
episodes.description: A staff member of Malaysian firm Global Ikhwan Services and Business Holdings (GISB) has been charged with alleged criminal intimidation. Mohamad Riza Makar, 39, allegedly intimidated a woman in a parking lot in Putrajaya, pressuring her to withdraw a police report she had filed. The accused, who has three wives and 10 children, allegedly threatened to disclose the whereabouts of the woman and her family. If convicted, he faces a fine and up to two years' jail. GISB is linked to over a dozen welfare homes that were raided last week, following reports of child abuse. Afifah Ariffin reports.

episodes.title: Malaysian king orders immediate, thorough investigation into alleged child abuse at welfare homes
episodes.description: The Malaysian king has ordered an immediate and thorough police investigation into allegations of child abuse and crimes that have shocked the nation. Last week, police carried out raids at 20 care homes and rescued over 400 children who were allegedly exploited and sexually abused. The victims are aged between one and 17 years old. The welfare homes are believed to be linked to Islamic conglomerate Global Ikhwan Services and Business (GISB). Afifah Ariffin reports from Kuala Lumpur.

episodes.title: Malaysian police rescue hundreds of children from suspected abuse in charity homes
episodes.description: Malaysian police are working with several ministries and agencies to complete the probe on alleged abuses of hundreds of children. This comes after the authorities raided more than a dozen charity homes on Sep 11. Meanwhile, child rights groups are demanding tougher laws and enhanced supervision to protect minors in the country. Afifah Ariffin has this story.

episodes.title: More than half of Japan's LDP lawmakers said to have ties to controversial church
episodes.description:
Japan’s ruling party has revealed that nearly half of its lawmakers had links with a controversial church group, which was entangled in the assassination of former leader Shinzo Abe. Mr Abe, Japan's longest-serving prime minister, was shot and killed at an election rally on Jul 8. The revelations have rocked the country, arousing widespread public opposition against Prime Minister Fumio Kishida’s decision to hold a state funeral for Mr Abe later this month.

episodes.title: Spotlight on Shincheonji religious sect in South Korea
episodes.description:
South Korea has the largest number of COVID-19 cases in Asia outside of China. Of more than 9,000 cases, about half can be traced back to a religious cult in the country's fourth-largest city. Even before the virus outbreak, the Shincheonji religious sect in Daegu was known for its secretive operations and fringe teachings.

episodes.title: COVID-19: Seoul's mayor sues Shincheonji Church of Jesus leaders over spike in cases
episodes.description:
The mayor of Seoul, Park Won-soon, is suing South Korea's Shincheonji Church of Jesus over the spike of COVID-19 cases in the country. There are now more than 4,800 confirmed cases of the virus in South Korea, and about half are linked to the church. CNA's Lim Yun Suk with more. https://cna.asia/39ot6So

For the latest developments on the #COVID19 outbreak: https://cna.asia/novelcoronavirus

episodes.title: Shincheonji leader apologises over COVID-19 outbreak as South Korea postpones opening of schools
episodes.description:
South Korea has delayed the start of the new school term by two weeks, as it continues to battle the largest COVID-19 outbreak outside of China. Almost 600 new cases have been confirmed, bringing the total to more than 4,300. The bulk of the new infections are linked to the Shincheonji religious sect. After weeks of criticism, the church's 88-year-old founder got down on his knees to apologise. The Seoul city government has filed a criminal complaint against Shincheonji after health authorities said they faced difficulties in contacting the church's 210,000 members to be tested for the virus. Mr Lee and several other church leaders could be charged with violating the disease control act, and even murder.

episodes.title: MHA investigating unregistered Singapore chapter of South Korean religious group Shincheonji
episodes.description:
Five South Koreans and two Singaporeans are helping with investigations into the unregistered Singapore chapter of South Korean religious group Shincheonji (SCJ). SCJ, which has been described as a cult, is at the centre of South Korea's COVID-19 outbreak. The Home Affairs Ministry said SCJ may have used deception to recruit followers from among Christian youths. The group had tried to register a company, which the ministry believes to be a front for its activities. Investigations revealed that SCJ had previously incorporated another front company and set up a purported training company. Home Affairs Minister K Shanmugam said people are entitled to freedom of religion, as long it is not criminal.

episodes.title: Shanmugam on the Singapore chapter of the South Korean Shincheonji cult being investigated by MHA
episodes.description:
The Singapore chapter of South Korean religious group Shincheonji Church of Jesus the Temple of the Tabernacle of the Testimony (SCJ) is being investigated by the Ministry of Home Affairs (MHA), which intends to take action to “proscribe” the group’s activities here. 
“(People) were being misled and defrauded into certain actions and the cult was behind it even though they put up front companies to carry out their actions”: Minister K Shanmugam told reporters. Read more: https://cna.asia/2I1RI7d
